manuscript.title: İlm-i Hâl
manuscript.notes: Anonymous, undated short Turkish-language catechetical text (ilm-i hâl) in 40 folios. Harekeli (fully vowelled) Nesih script. The opening bifolio (ff. 1b–2a) is decorated with gold halkâr margin paintings and an illuminated serlevha. The binding uses ebrulu kâğıt (marbled paper) on covers, with brown leather spine and edges — this marbled paper is a binding feature, not page decoration, and has been distinguished from the halkâr page margin programme. Gold roundel duraklar appear in the text block.

paper_decoration.summary: The opening bifolio (ff. 1b–2a) features gold halkâr (halkârî) margin painting with scrolling vine and leaf motifs throughout the margins of both pages. An illuminated headpiece (serlevha) is present on the right-hand page (f. 1b). Gold roundel duraklar (verse/section markers) punctuate the text. The halkâr is executed in gold technique with organic, flowing scrollwork. The binding incorporates ebrulu kâğıt (marbled paper) as cover paper, but this is a binding decoration only and has no bearing on the classification of the page paper decoration. The full extent of the halkâr programme beyond ff. 1b–2a is unconfirmed.

technique_terms.ottoman: halkârî tezyinatlıdır; serlevha; durak; ebrulu cilt kâğıdı

key_indicators: Gold halkâr with scrolling vine and leaf motifs: standard Ottoman luxury halkâr vocabulary
Illuminated serlevha with gold and colour on opening folio: consistent with Ottoman manuscript conventions
Gold roundel duraklar in text: characteristic Ottoman Quranic/religious text decoration
Short ilm-i hâl format with luxury opening decoration: a common Ottoman pattern for devotional gift manuscripts
Ebrulu kâğıt binding covers: confirms Ottoman production context (marbled paper bindings standard in Ottoman Istanbul)
cross_tradition_caveats: Manuscript is undated and anonymous; no colophon, no patron name, no dated comparable in the opening
Workshop centre entirely undetermined; could range from Istanbul to any Ottoman provincial centre capable of halkâr work
Low attribution confidence (0.40) reflects absence of any dating or provenance anchor beyond the broad Ottoman tradition identification

paper.description: Not individually described in catalogue. Text paper assumed plain (uncolored, undecorated) based on absence of any kâğıt özellikleri record.
paper.color: Not described; text pages presumably plain

ruling.description: Ruling details not recorded in catalogue; cetvels implied by the halkâr framing context

binding.description: Ebrulu kâğıt (marbled paper) covers, with brown leather (kahverengi deri) at edges and spine, on board (mukavva). The marbled paper is a binding cover feature, not a page paper decoration.
binding.material: marbled paper covers; brown leather spine and edges; board (mukavva)

codicology.condition_summary: No condition issues noted in catalogue record. Opening bifolio decoration appears intact at IIIF viewer resolution.

limitations: Only the opening bifolio (p004 IIIF viewer page) was examined; full extent of decoration programme beyond ff. 1b–2a not verified
Gold halkâr brushwork detail not fully resolvable at IIIF viewer resolution
Binding ebrulu kâğıt (marbled paper covers) not examined at high resolution; marbled paper type (battal, hatip, etc.) undetermined

decoration_observed: Gold halkâr ornamentation filling all margins of both pages: flowing scrolling vine and leaf motifs in gold technique
Illuminated headpiece (serlevha) on right page (f. 1b): coloured and gold
Gold roundel duraklar (section markers) visible in text block
Text in Harekeli Nesih (fully vowelled Naskh) script, confirming religious/catechetical genre
folio_analyses.notes: Organic flowing gold halkâr scrollwork clearly visible in margins. The vine-and-leaf vocabulary is less elaborately naturalistic than the polychrome shükûfe halkâr of muglali_hoca_mustafa_00035; this is a monochrome (gold-only) halkâr programme consistent with a simpler but still luxury Ottoman devotional manuscript.

terms_used.english: Shaded gold floral or foliate painting in manuscript margins; here executed in gold only (monochrome gold halkâr)
Illuminated headpiece at the opening of a text
Roundel or rosette used as a section or verse marker within the text block; in Ottoman religious texts often in gold
Ottoman Turkish devotional/catechetical manual covering religious duties; the most widely produced Ottoman popular religious text
Marbled paper used here on the binding covers only; not page decoration
Frame ruling around the text block

Holding of Ottoman court-adjacent devotional texts with halkâr openings; provides high-quality comparanda for gold halkâr vine-scroll programmes.

provenance.notes: Donated to Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi as part of the Yazma Bağışlar (Manuscript Donations) collection. Identity of donor and earlier provenance unknown.

analysis_metadata.image_quality_notes: IIIF viewer resolution sufficient for macro-level halkâr identification and classification. Fine gold brushwork detail within the halkâr not fully resolvable. Serlevha colour values readable.
analysis_metadata.folios_not_examined: Approximately 38 remaining text folios not examined. Full extent of halkâr decoration beyond the opening bifolio unverified.
